ETYMOLOGY: From Latin aether, from Greek aithēr 'upper air', from aithein 'to burn, shine'.
SINCE: Late Middle English (for 'upper air'); mid-18th century (for chemical compound)

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: The upper regions of air beyond the clouds; the heavens.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 高空；上层大气；天堂；苍穹。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The stars twinkled brightly in the clear night ether.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 繁星在清澈的夜空中闪烁。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A pleasant-smelling, colorless, volatile liquid (specifically diethyl ether) that is highly flammable, used as an anesthetic and as a solvent.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 乙醚；醚（一种无色易燃的液体，有愉快气味，用作麻醉剂和溶剂）。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The patient was put under using ether before the surgery.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 病人在手术前被麻醉剂乙醚麻醉。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: (Historical Physics) A hypothetical substance formerly thought to fill all space, through which electromagnetic waves were propagated.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: （旧物理学）以太；一种曾被认为充满整个空间、传播电磁波的假想物质。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The Michelson-Morley experiment aimed to detect the luminiferous ether.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 迈克尔逊-莫雷实验旨在检测光以太。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: (Informal) The invisible medium through which radio waves, internet data, etc., travel; the airwaves or cyberspace.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: （非正式）空中电波；网络空间；无线电波、互联网数据等传播的无形介质。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: My email must have gotten lost somewhere in the ether.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 我的电子邮件肯定在某个地方迷失在网络空间里了。

REGISTER: Varies by meaning: poetic/literary, scientific/medical, or informal modern usage.
